abstract: The diaries show Ronald Reagan as a more active and alert chief executive than his detractors care to admit.
snippet: The diaries show Ronald Reagan as a more active and alert chief executive than his detractors care to admit.
lead_paragraph: Not since the 19th century has a United States president kept a diary through his entire White House tenure, and this volume tells us more about Ronald Reagan than many of his biographies. Besides which, not a few interpretive bits of gold are sprinkled amid the grit and gravel of diplomatic niceties, Congressional consultations and after-dinner entertainments.

lead_paragraph: The painters finished retouching the kitchen last week. An electrician was in the basement. The hospital bed arrived Monday and was placed in Steven Domalewski’s new room.

abstract: Many doctors who were sanctioned by a medical board were later paid for research by drug makers.
snippet: Many doctors who were sanctioned by a medical board were later paid for research by drug makers.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago the Minnesota Board of Medical Practice accused Dr. Faruk Abuzzahab of a “reckless, if not willful, disregard” for the welfare of 46 patients, 5 of whom died in his care or shortly afterward. The board suspended his license for seven months and restricted it for two years after that.

abstract: The eight candidates vying to be the Democrat nominee for president in the 2008 elections answered questions submitted by CNN and YouTube users in a debate. Moderator: Anderson Cooper, CNN host. Location: the Citadel, Charleston, S.C. Monday, July 23, 2007. Here is a full transcript of the event, from CNN:.

abstract: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is usually caused by smoking, has become a major killer in women.
snippet: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is usually caused by smoking, has become a major killer in women.
lead_paragraph: For Jean Rommes, the crisis came five years ago, on a Monday morning when she had planned to go to work but wound up in the hospital, barely able to breathe. She was 59, the president of a small company in Iowa. Although she had quit smoking a decade earlier, 30 years of cigarettes had taken their toll.
headline.main: From Smoking Boom, a Major Killer of Women
headline.print_headline: From Smoking Boom, a Major Killer of Women

abstract: Booth Gardner, a former governor of Washington State who has Parkinson's, is urgently lobbying for a doctor-assisted-suicide law. His son is among those fighting him every step of the way.
snippet: Booth Gardner, a former governor of Washington State who has Parkinson's, is urgently lobbying for a doctor-assisted-suicide law. His son is among those fighting him every step of the way.
lead_paragraph: "This will be my last campaign,” Booth Gardner said. “This will be the biggest fight of my career.” He walked along the lane between the beach of driftwood and his compound of houses. The driftwood clotted the shore; it was the end of summer now, and the cove was still, but in winter massive branches and trunks churn up out of the water of Puget Sound. Bone-white roots clawed at the air on this late afternoon; Gardner’s grandchildren climbed across them. His walk was a vigorous lurch. One foot twisted inward, one knee buckled. His torso keeled slightly with each step. He has Parkinson’s. He was governor of Washington State for two terms in the 1980s and ’90s. He is 71, and his last campaign is driven by his desire to kill himself. “I can’t see where anybody benefits by my hanging around,” he told me, while his blond grandchildren, sticks prodding, explored the water’s edge.

abstract: A look at the curious writerly firm of Amis & Amis, founded by Kingsley Amis, an indelible figure in British letters, and run today by his son Martin, a more daring and inventive novelist than his father.
snippet: A look at the curious writerly firm of Amis & Amis, founded by Kingsley Amis, an indelible figure in British letters, and run today by his son Martin, a more daring and inventive novelist than his father.
lead_paragraph: Ben Jonson wrote: “Greatness of name in the father oft-times helps not forth, but overwhelms the son; they stand too near one another. The shadow kills the growth.” This Oedipal principle applies to all sorts of professions, but few more so than the literary one. It’s not unheard of for the child of an author to try his hand at writing. Stephen King’s two sons are writers, and so is one of John Updike’s. Hilma Wolitzer’s daughter Meg is a novelist, as is Anita Desai’s daughter Kiran, whose second book just won the Booker Prize — an award that has so far eluded her mother. But writers’ offspring tend to go into the family business with far less regularity than, say, the children of doctors or lawyers, and it seldom happens that over the long haul, and in the deepening shade, the younger equals or outstrips the elder — the way that Anthony Trollope, to take a famous example, bested his mother, Fanny.

abstract: Auditory hallucinations have long been understood as a sign of severe mental illness. For some, that’s part of the problem.
snippet: Auditory hallucinations have long been understood as a sign of severe mental illness. For some, that’s part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: Angelo, a London-born scientist in his early 30s with sandy brown hair, round wire-frame glasses and a slight, unobtrusive stammer, vividly recalls the day he began to hear voices. It was Jan. 7, 2001, and he had recently passed his Ph.D. oral exams in chemistry at an American university, where, for the previous four and a half years, he conducted research into infrared electromagnetism. Angelo was walking home from the laboratory when, all of a sudden, he heard two voices in his head. “It was like hearing thoughts in my mind that were not mine,” he explained recently. “They identified themselves as Andrew and Oliver, two angels. In my mind’s eye, I could see an image of a bald, middle-aged man dressed in white against a white background. This, I was told, was Oliver.” What the angels said, to Angelo’s horror, was that in the coming days, he would die of a brain hemorrhage. Terrified, Angelo hurried home and locked himself into his apartment. For three long days he waited out his fate, at which time his supervisor drove him to a local hospital, where Angelo was admitted to the psychiatric ward. It was his first time under psychiatric care. He had never heard voices before. His diagnosis was schizophrenia with depressive overtones.

abstract: A front-page article yesterday about living with the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease misstated the number of couples New York University had planned to accommodate in counseling sessions for Alzheimer’s patients and their spouses, and included erroneous information from the university on how many signed up. The sessions were to include 100 couples, not 200, and 26 couples enrolled, not 16. Also, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Peter Hebert, who advocates for patients in Northern California. As the article noted, he is 67, not 76.

abstract: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Ben Weisman, a songwriter, included erroneous information from a family member about his illnesses before his death. He suffered a stroke and had pneumonia; he did not have Alzheimer’s disease. The obituary also erroneously included a group among the performers for whom he wrote songs. He did not write for the Beatles.

abstract: I became immersed in your special issue on aging boomers (May 6). I enjoyed the Ethicist, who wrote that if my wife told me she didn’t want to have sex anymore, I could avoid “abnegation of erotic happiness” with someone else as long as I got her permission. But forget about sex. Forget about everything at my age. That’s why Rob Walker’s article about the “plasticity” of the brain caught my attention (Consumed, “Muscular Metaphor”). Companies are offering “fitter brain” products to keep you on the edge, and boomers are signing up for adult-education classes to “keep their brains at a high level.” Although in “A Longer, Better Life,” Sara Davidson asked if doing crossword puzzles can prevent Alzheimer’s disease, and the answer was not encouraging.

abstract: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an increase in aid to the Palestinian Authority in 2006 despite an international embargo imposed after the Islamic militant group Hamas came to power misstated the political affiliation of Salam Fayyad, the finance minister in the new Palestinian unity government. He belongs to the Third Way, a party he started in 2006; he is no longer a member of Fatah, the political organization that is a Hamas rival. Also, a caption with the article misstated the type of aid that Mr. Fayyad said had more than doubled in 2006 compared with 2005. It was money to support the Palestinian Authority’s budget — not the total amount of aid, including humanitarian, for Palestinians.
